channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: France Pushes for Biden-Putin Meeting
item.description: President Biden has “agreed in principle” to meet the Russian leader if there is no invasion. Mr. Biden has stepped up his warnings about Moscow’s plans after seeing evidence that an attack on Ukraine was imminent.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Russia May Be Seeking Pretext for Ukraine Invasion, Officials Say
item.description: The pressure on Kyiv mounted after a weekend of shelling and evacuations in the east, and the extension of war games in neighboring Belarus.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Servant of the People (Ukrainian Political Party)
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evacuees from the separatist-held region of eastern Ukraine on Sunday at a temporary shelter in Taganrog, Russia. Many were anxious about how long they might be displaced and about what might lie ahead.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Tests Positive for Covid-19, as England Moves to Relax Rules
item.description: The queen, who recently marked her 70th anniversary on the throne, has faced a series of health issues since late last year.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II this month at Sandringham House in Norfolk, England. Buckingham Palace said on Sunday that she was “experiencing mild coldlike symptoms.”

item.title: Lukashenko Once Kept Russia at a Distance. Now He Is a Docile Putin Satrap.
item.description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus once skillfully managed Moscow, but now he is doing the Kremlin’s bidding in Russia’s confrontation with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus attending joint military exercises between Russia and Belarus on Thursday near Asipovichy, Belarus.

item.title: Dead Body Is Pulled From Burning Ferry Off Greece, With 10 Still Missing
item.description: At least one person was confirmed to have died on the Euroferry Olympia, which caught fire on Friday and is still ablaze near the island of Corfu. Hundreds of others have been rescued.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: The Euroferry Olympia, near the Greek island of Corfu, on Sunday. The cause of the fire on the ship has not yet been established.

item.title: India’s Congress Party Faces a Test of Survival as Punjab Votes
item.description: A defeat here, one of the few states where the once-dominant party still retains power, would be a major blow.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Charanjit Singh Channi arriving for a Congress party meeting in Jhabal Kalan, India, on Thursday. He is seeking election to the position he was appointed to, chief minister of Punjab.

item.title: Conflict and Climate Change Ravage Syria’s Agricultural Heartland
item.description: Drought and a decade of war have brought failing crops and poverty to a region once known as Syria’s breadbasket. Even the bread has changed.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Farmers in northeast Syria say their sheep are thinner, less healthy and selling for much less.

item.title: Soaring Energy Bills Deepen Crisis for Turks, and Erdogan
item.description: Hit by spiraling inflation, electricity bills have doubled for households and businesses in only a month.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: A bar in Istanbul on Wednesday. The cost of power has doubled in some parts of Turkey, fueling widespread discontent.

item.title: Shelling Escalates in Ukraine as Thousands Flee, Fearing Attack
item.description: Western leaders repeat calls for a diplomatic resolution to the crisis. Russia fires missiles in a blunt warning of where the conflict could lead.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: At the front line on Saturday in Krymske, Ukraine, where a building was damaged by mortar fire overnight.

item.title: In Ukraine Crisis, the Looming Threat of a New Cold War
item.description: If he invades, President Vladimir V. Putin is inviting a new global struggle with the West. He should think about how the last one ended, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on the front lines in eastern Ukraine, which is seen as a likely flashpoint in a broader war.

item.title: A Press Tour Turns Frantic in Ukraine As Russia-Backed Shelling Intensifies
item.description: As shelling intensified in eastern Ukraine, a seemingly routine press tour turned into a frantic rush to safety.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Andrew E. Kramer and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops in Luhansk Oblast, eastern Ukraine, on Saturday, a day after mortar attacks continued through the night.

item.title: Highgate Cemetery: A City of the Dead That Inspires the Living
item.description: Highgate Cemetery is the final resting place for about 170,000 Londoners, among them the famous, the infamous and the ordinary. Since the start of the pandemic, its leafy pathways have taken on new meaning for some in the city.

item.title: Putin’s Baseless Claims of Genocide Hint at More Than War
item.description: The invocations serve to justify not just Moscow’s actions in Ukraine, but also its wider quest for a new imperial identity rooted in Russian ethnicity.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at a virtual Security Council meeting on Friday. Analysts and the West say his use of certain language may indicate a prelude to invasion.

item.title: Ex-Modeling Agent and Epstein Associate Found Dead in a Paris Jail
item.description: Jean-Luc Brunel had been charged with the rape of minors and was suspected of scouting young girls for Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The Sante prison in Paris where Jean-Luc Brunel was being held.

item.title: If War Flames in Ukraine, These 2 Odd Little Enclaves May Be the Spark
item.description: Russian-backed separatists in the Luhansk and Donetsk regions once got just passing attention. They loom much larger now as many fear what may come next in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gleb Yegorov, 17, at the bus station in Stanytsia Luhanska, Ukraine, on Sunday. He said he left separatist eastern Ukraine to avoid being drafted.

item.title: Satellite Images Show New Phase of Russian Military Readiness
item.description: Several units or troops have been deployed outside of bases or training grounds, as Russian units continue moving closer to the border with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl

item.title: Israel to Open Borders to Unvaccinated Tourists
item.description: After weathering the Omicron wave, the country is turning to testing to try to let in more visitors safely.
item.dc:creator: Ada Petriczko
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Tsafrir Abayov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Starting March 1, Prime Minister Naftali Bennett will allow foreign tourists into Israel regardless of vaccine status.

item.title: Ukraine's Zelensky Accuses Western of Appeasement
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine reminded his Western counterparts of what was supposed to be an unforgettable lesson from Europe’s past.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine denounced the possibility of appeasing Russia in a speech on Saturday at the Munich Security Conference.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Shelling in Ukraine intensifies
item.description: Plus the Olympics end and Queen Elizabeth II tests positive.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: What if Queen Elizabeth Were Too Ill to Carry Out Her Duties?
item.description: According to Buckingham Palace, if the queen needs to suspend her official duties because of illness or because she is abroad, two or more counselors of state can act on her behalf.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Charles and Prince William in November in Glasgow. Either could be called on to fill in for Queen Elizabeth II if she were unable to perform her duties.

item.title: Ukrainian Expats Express Solidarity With Homeland
item.description: At a rally in London, many of the attendees said they hoped that a full-scale Russian invasion could be averted.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Demonstrators in London on Saturday showed support for Ukraine. The rally convened at the foot of a statue of Volodymyr the Great, a symbol of Ukrainian nationalism.

item.title: In a Call with Putin, Macron Pursues a Diplomatic Solution in Ukraine
item.description: But the Kremlin signaled little optimism regarding a diplomatic path, saying Western countries were pushing Ukraine’s government to a “military solution.”
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, left, welcoming President Emmanuel Macron of France before their talks this month in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.

item.title: Data Leak Exposes How a Swiss Bank Served Strongmen and Spies
item.description: Leaked data on more than 18,000 accounts shows that the Swiss bank missed or ignored red flags.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Drucker and Ben Hubbard

item.title: People From Eastern Ukraine Are Evacuating to Russia as Tensions Continue
item.description: Refugees crossed into Russia after a warning from Kremlin-backed rebel leaders that Ukraine was about to launch an attack on the separatist areas.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees at a train station in Taganrog, Russia, on Sunday. They are part of a growing evacuation from eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Biden Is Still Willing to Talk to Putin, Blinken Says
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said Russia was taking steps leading to an invasion of Ukraine — including keeping troops in Belarus — but the U.S. is still ready to engage in diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken at the Munich Security Conference in Germany on Saturday.

item.title: The queen’s illness spurs an outpouring of support and concern.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in the House of Lords in May during the state opening of Parliament. A wave of encouragement and support erupted after news of her coronavirus infection.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Held an Audience at Windsor Castle Days Before Testing Positive
item.description: The queen met with members of the military in her first in-person engagement since her son Prince Charles tested positive.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II meeting members of the military on Wednesday at Windsor Castle.

item.title: Why the Queen's Illness Comes at Awkward Time for Boris Johnson
item.description: Before Queen Elizabeth II’s diagnosis, Prime Minister Boris Johnson had been expected to announce the lifting of the remaining coronavirus restrictions in England.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Outside a theater in London last month. In the past week, Britain has recorded more than 300,000 new cases of the coronavirus.

item.title: American Self-censorship
item.description: U.S. institutions are increasingly silencing themselves to win access to China.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Actor John Cena apologized for calling Taiwan a country in an interview promoting the movie "F9: The Fast Saga."

item.title: With Olympics Closing Ceremony, China Celebrates a Joyless Triumph
item.description: The Games ended without disaster but overshadowed by a doping scandal, rising tensions in Europe and anxiety over the future of the sporting movement.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Kevin Draper
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: As athletes marched into the Bird’s Nest stadium in Beijing on Sunday, China closed the most contentious Olympics in years.

item.title: Amid Ukraine Crisis, China and Russia's Bond Alarms U.S. and Europe
item.description: The Biden administration plans to build up global coalitions to counter a pact between Vladimir V. Putin and Xi Jinping, portending a new type of Cold War.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and President Xi Jinping of China in Beijing this month. U.S. and European officials are troubled by what is effectively a nonaggression pact between China and Russia.

item.title: Shelling and evacuations in Ukraine’s east could give Putin a pretext to invade.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The village of Vrubivka, Ukraine, which is roughly nine miles from the line of contact with a gray zone occupied by Russian-backed separatists, was hit on Friday by artillery fire.

item.title: A Covid pill from Merck showed more promise in reducing the risk of hospitalization in a recent study.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:description: Merck’s antiviral Covid treatment, molnupiravir.

item.title: Shelling escalates in eastern Ukraine, as U.S. officials warn of pretexts for a Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian refugees board buses in Avilo-Upsenka, Russia, after fleeing a separatist-held area of eastern Ukraine on Saturday.

item.title: Counting Russian troops is an imprecise science.
item.description: American officials said a new troop estimate includes some forces that were not previously counted — most notably Russian forces in Crimea, as well as separatist forces in the Donbas region.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A tactical exercise last month in the Rostov region of Russia, near Ukraine’s border.

item.title: Storm Eunice Kills at Least 8
item.description: Gusts toppled trees and sent debris flying, leaving tens of thousands without power and disrupting travel a day later.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: Strong winds affected waves in Porthcawl, Wales, on Friday.

item.title: The Search Has Begun for an Antarctic Pioneer’s Lost Ship
item.description: Explorers have started combing the Weddell Sea for one of the most revered ships in the history of polar exploration, Ernest Shackleton’s Endurance, which sank in 1915.
item.dc:creator: Esther Horvath and Henry Fountain

item.title: Biden extends the national pandemic emergency first declared in March 2020.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nurse administers a coronavirus test on Friday in Hagerstown, Md.

item.title: China’s foreign minister calls for new negotiations and respect for ‘territorial integrity.’
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Ukrainian Army soldiers at the front line of the conflict with Russian-backed rebels in the Luhansk region of eastern Ukraine on Saturday.

item.title: U.S. Lifts Temporary Ban on Avocados From Mexico
item.description: The ban was issued last week after a U.S. inspector was verbally threatened in the state of Michoacán in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: Workers at an avocado packing plant in Uruapan in the Mexican state of Michoacán on Wednesday.

item.title: President Zelensky criticizes the allied response to Russia’s buildup.
item.description: The Ukrainian leader thanked the West but said sanctions should be applied now and that repeated predictions of imminent war were damaging.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, left, and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, in Munich on Saturday.

item.title: Police in Ottawa Rout Truckers With a Show of Force
item.description: A central area of the protest that roiled Canada’s capital for three weeks was cleared of demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers clearing protestors in Ottawa on Saturday.

item.title: Intense shelling rocks eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian man ducks for cover during incoming artillery fire near the front line between Ukraine and Russia-backed separatists near Svitlodarsk on Saturday.

item.title: Many fleeing to Russia from eastern Ukraine blame Kyiv for the intensifying conflict.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People’s Republic arriving at a border crossing in Avilo-Uspenka, Russia, on Saturday.

item.title: Peek inside the Times Sunday Magazine at the future of work.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Russia and Belarus Stage Pretend Battle as Threat of Real One Looms in Ukraine
item.description: A 10-day joint exercise involves the biggest deployment of Russian troops on the territory of Belarus since the end of the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins

item.title: How Life Resumes
item.description: We can wait for normal life to return, or we can just start living.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Kamala Harris Says West Faces ‘Defining Moment’ Over Ukraine
item.description: The vice president’s first public remarks on the Ukraine crisis were watched with scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris addressed the Munich Security Conference on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Paramilitaries Prepare for Conflict With Russia.
item.description: Times journalists followed the members of one such group
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Brent McDonald and Dmitriy Khavin

item.title: Fears grow in eastern Ukraine as shelling picks up in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer

item.title: An Earlier Trek to Ottawa Had a Different Tone but Still Captured the Nation
item.description: Deep in the Great Depression, about 1,000 men attempted to reach Ottawa to reform relief programs. Most didn’t make it but they eventually achieved their aims.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: A swell of police officers closed in on the encampment of truckers on Friday.

item.title: Why Ukraine Matters: What to Know About the Crisis With Russia
item.description: Here’s how the country ended up at the center of a global crisis.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier this month in Luhansk Oblast, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: When Architects Made Worlds
item.description: MoMA explores an era of sweeping change, when South Asian architects — pioneering women, among them — redefined the postcolonial era and helped construct new nation states.
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman
item.category: The Project of Independence: Architectures of Decolonization in South Asia, 1947-1985 (Exhibit)

item.title: Zelensky leaves Ukraine, heading to Munich to rally Western support.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky, front right, attending a military drill in northern Ukraine on Wednesday.

item.title: President Zelensky asks the West to make no deals ‘behind our back’ as the threat to Ukraine grows.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a front line position in Krymsk, eastern Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: As warnings of war grow louder, Ukrainians try to keep their bearings.
item.description: The crisis has taken a toll on many Ukrainians.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on Friday in the Luhansk region of eastern Ukraine, near a crater left by shelling. A conflict with separatists has been under way there for years.

item.title: Biden Says Putin Has Chosen ‘Catastrophic’ War Over Diplomacy
item.description: President Biden spoke amid fears that Russia was setting the stage for an invasion that could ignite the biggest conflict in Europe in decades.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: President Joe Biden at the Roosevelt Room in Washington, D.C. on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Surgeon General and Family Have Covid
item.description: The doctor and his wife tested positive after caring for their two sick children.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, the U.S. surgeon general, at the White House in July. “When you’ve been as safe as you can, getting Covid-19 can be frustrating and disappointing,” he said on Friday.

item.title: Videos show reported explosions near Luhansk.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl, Brenna Smith, Haley Willis and Masha Froliak
